question:
These questions are based on A.H. Mohammed's The Last Days at Forcados High School.

At the end of term in Forcados High School. Nene was saddled with the responsibility of
option_a: leading her house in the race
option_c: arranging the school hall for dinner

question: Efua was not in the good books of teachers at Forcados High School because
option_a: the students of Forcados did not like her
option_b: she was expelled from her previous school
option_c: she bribed the principal before she was admitted
option_d: her admission into senior class was unusual

question: In the novel, Ansa looked around glumly when Jimi was engrossed in laughter and chatter because he was
option_c: distracted by a band playing on the field
option_d: given twelve strokes of the cane by the principal

question: Mama Shilifat had an affection for Jimi because she always gave him
option_c: the courage to do well in his class

question:
Ansa licked his lips and said furtively, look this is between you and me. Jimi would be angry if i told you nut his brother is well, we suspect he sometimes sells drugs and...'

From the excerpt above, Ansa was talking to
The speculation amongst the students of Forcados High School was that Jimi was dating
Mr Solade sent Jimi to Ibadan for the holidays in order to
option_a: save Jimi from Wole's bad influence
option_b: heed Jimi's request to stay with his friends
option_c: allow Jimi spend some time with his friends
option_d: allow Jimi to know more about Ibadan

question: Students refused to sympathize with Efua when drinks spilled on her because
option_a: she would not accept their sympathy
option_c: they planned it to disgrace her

question: Which of the following best describes Mr Mallum?
option_a: He was a fat, tall man with wimpish behaviour
option_b: He was a tall, wiry man with good diction
option_c: He was crude, rash and impatient
option_d: He was a small, wiry man with odd accent

question: According to the novel, Efua was in Forcados High School because
option_a: her stepfather was a board member
option_c: the school needed her mother's support
option_d: of aunt Moni's gift to the school

question:
Jimi and Efua, there's something fishy going on there....

From the exercept above, the expression...something fishy refers to
option_a: Nene's fear that Efua and Jimi were no longer going out
option_b: Nene's fear that Jimi was not determined to jilt Efua
option_c: Nene's annoyance that Efua might snatch Jimi from her
option_d: Nen's suspicion that Jimi and Efua were having a relationship

question: Seyi Lawal, the head boy of the school was described as someone who
The author uses the novel to portray some of the
Efua's guarded and hostile attitude towards boys could be traced to
option_a: the teachings she had from her cleric
option_b: stories she had heard from her aunt
option_c: the experience she had with her stepfather

question: Jimi was very prominent in Forcados High School because he was
option_a: the son of a great scholar
option_b: the only child of his parents

question:
For this question, select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the question.

Mr. Rufus bore the brunt in the last promotion examination.
option_a: Mr Rufus failed the examination woefully
option_b: Mr Rufus excelled in the examination
option_c: Mr. Rufus was excited about the examination
option_d: Mr. Rufus toyed with the examination

My friend is well off nowadays
option_b: My friend is well known to people

question:

option_a: His activity brought disrepute to the nation
option_b: His service to the nation was not exemplary
option_c: He was showered with the responsibilty of the yeoman
option_d: He was very loyal to the nation

option_a: He did not agree with the situation
option_b: He used his experience to settle the sitution
option_c: He saved himself out of the situation
option_d: He found himself deeply involved in the situation

option_a: They are about to agree with each other
option_b: They are about to accept other people's opinion
option_c: They are about to hit each other
option_d: They are about to disagree with other people's

question:

By refusing the offer, he has just cut down his own throat
option_a: He has made a big mistake
option_b: He has made the right decision
option_c: He has given up on his idea
option_d: He has used the Knife on his throat

For this question, select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the question.

These job cuts are just the thin end of the wedge
option_c: Job cuts are the beginning of unpleasant situations
option_d: Job cuts are the beginning of healthy rivalries

question:
For this question, select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the question.

Jumai will do well if she was given a fair crack of the whip.
option_a: She would do well if she was given a fair whip
option_b: She would excel if she used the whip well
option_c: She would do well if she was given equal opportunity
option_d: She would do well if she was made to cry

Read the passage carefully and answer the question that follows.

Curiosity is as clear and definite as any of our urges. We wonder what is in a sealed telegram or in a letter which someone else is absorbed or what is being said in the telephone booth or in low conversation. This inquisitiveness is vastly stimulated by jealousy. Suspicion or any hint that we ourselves are directly or indirectly involved in. But there appears to be a fair amount of personal interest in other people's affairs even when they do not concern us except as a mystery to be unravelled or a tale to be told. The reports of a divorce suit will have news 'value' for many weeks, They constitute a story like a novel, a play or a moving picture. This is not an example of pure curiosity. However, since we readily identify ourselves with others' their joys and despair then become our own concern.

Adapted from Harris, W. and L.G Wilson (1963) The University Handbook,New York: Holt Rinehart and Winston





Which of the following statements is true according to the passage? A Suspicion often stimulates inquisitiveness B Every human conduct often gives rise to curiosity C Our environment always inhibits curiosity D Curiosity is effective where there is no room for it Answer & Comment B Comment Advertisement

(adsbygoogle = window.adsbygoogle || []).push({});
option_b: Every human conduct often gives rise to curiosity
option_d: Curiosity is effective where there is no room for it

From the passage, it can be deduced that curiosity thrives A through conducts that are inimical to our activities B if we are able to probe into what others are thinking C only if we become suspicious of people's motives D if the subject of discussion is of interest to us Answer & Comment C Comment
option_a: through conducts that are inimical to our activities
option_b: if we are able to probe into what others are thinking
option_c: only if we become suspicious of people's motives
option_d: if the subject of discussion is of interest to us
